and Current Status

UC TSR&TP Advisory Committee Spring Meeting Cal EPA, Sacramento March 17, 2003

Cal EPA, Sacramento
March 17, 2003

Gordon Schremp California Energy Commission gschremp@energy.state.ca.us

California Energy Commission
gschremp@energy.state.ca.us

Introduction

the use of MTBE

Background - MTBE Use
Background - MTBE Use

MTBE used in gasoline since late 1970s Required seasonal use beginning 1992 – Winter oxygenated fuels program – Designed to reduce carbon monoxide emissions – Most refiners selected MTBE – Approximately 11 percent of gasoline volume Mandated year-round use in 1995 & 1996 – Reformulated gasoline (RFG) program to control emissions of toxics and pollutants that contribute to the formation of photochemical smog
MTBE used in gasoline since late 1970s
Required seasonal use beginning 1992
– Winter oxygenated fuels program
– Designed to reduce carbon monoxide emissions
– Most refiners selected MTBE
– Approximately 11 percent of gasoline volume
Mandated year-round use in 1995 & 1996
– Reformulated gasoline (RFG) program to control
emissions of toxics and pollutants that contribute
to the formation of photochemical smog

– Federal law requires minimum use of oxygenates
– Federal law requires minimum use of oxygenates

in all RFG regions (2 percent by weight)
in all RFG regions (2 percent by weight)

– California regulations permit discretionary use, but 3
– California regulations permit discretionary use, but
3

federal mandate applies to 80 percent of State
federal mandate applies to 80 percent of State

Background - MTBE Use (cont.)
Background - MTBE Use (cont.)

Gasoline demand and supply – Gasoline demand in California during 2003
Gasoline demand and supply
– Gasoline demand in California during 2003

estimated in range of 15.6 to 16 billion gallons – Demand expected to increase between 1.6 and 3
estimated in range of 15.6 to 16 billion gallons
– Demand expected to increase between 1.6 and 3

percent per year
percent per year

– Refineries located in California produce the
– Refineries located in California produce the

majority of gasoline for the State
majority of gasoline for the State

– Imports of gasoline and blending components increase each year, while refinery capacity remains relatively flat (annual growth rate of 0.5 percent)
– Imports of gasoline and blending components
increase each year, while refinery capacity
remains relatively flat (annual growth rate of 0.5
percent)

– California represents nearly 12 percent of United
– California represents nearly 12 percent of United

States gasoline demand
States gasoline demand

Background - MTBE Use (cont.)
Background - MTBE Use (cont.)

Types and quantities of fuel oxygenates – MTBE is primary oxygenate of choice
Types and quantities of fuel oxygenates
– MTBE is primary oxygenate of choice

• Superior blending properties
• Superior blending properties

– 1.4 billion gallons blended in California gasoline
– 1.4 billion gallons blended in California gasoline

during 2002
during 2002

– Blending concentration of over 9 volume percent
– Blending concentration of over 9 volume percent

for entire gasoline pool
for entire gasoline pool

– Ethanol use in 2002 less than 100 million gallons • ConocoPhillips was first company to use ethanol in
– Ethanol use in 2002 less than 100 million gallons
• ConocoPhillips was first company to use ethanol in

California reformulated gasoline
California reformulated gasoline

MTBE concentration declining over time
MTBE concentration declining over time

Factors Associated with Decision to Phase Out the Use of MTBE
Factors Associated with Decision to
Phase Out the Use of MTBE

Water resource contamination concerns – Detections of MTBE in water wells – Prediction that contamination would spread and
Water resource contamination concerns
– Detections of MTBE in water wells
– Prediction that contamination would spread and

cleanup costs dramatically increase Potential health concerns also raised Studies ordered by California Legislature to determine: – Cost to eliminate MTBE – Assess risk to people and the environment of
cleanup costs dramatically increase
Potential health concerns also raised
Studies ordered by California Legislature to
determine:
– Cost to eliminate MTBE
– Assess risk to people and the environment of

continued use
continued use

– Initial work conducted by California Energy Commission and University of California
– Initial work conducted by California Energy
Commission and University of California

Factors Associated with Decision to Phase Out the Use of MTBE (cont.)
Factors Associated with Decision to
Phase Out the Use of MTBE (cont.)

Initial studies completed by late 1998 – UC - Annual water remediation costs estimated at
Initial studies completed by late 1998
– UC - Annual water remediation costs estimated at

$340 MM to $1.5 billion
$340 MM to $1.5 billion

– CEC - Gasoline production cost would only
– CEC - Gasoline production cost would only

increase 2 - 3 cents per gallon with use of ethanol • Annual cost to California consumers of $300 to $450
increase 2 - 3 cents per gallon with use of ethanol
• Annual cost to California consumers of $300 to $450

million
million

Executive Order issued by Governor Davis during March 1999 – Phases out use of MTBE by December 31, 2002 – California Air Resources Board (ARB) amends gasoline specifications banning MTBE, ethanol only acceptable fuel oxygenate substitute
Executive Order issued by Governor Davis
during March 1999
– Phases out use of MTBE by December 31, 2002
– California Air Resources Board (ARB) amends
gasoline specifications banning MTBE, ethanol
only acceptable fuel oxygenate substitute

Subsequent Actions - 1999
Subsequent Actions - 1999

Energy Commission determines that timetable to remove MTBE cannot be advanced ARB adopts Phase 3 RFG regulations – Ethanol only permissible oxygenate – Gasoline specifications changed • lowers sulfur from 40 to 20 ppm • lowers benzene from 1.0 to 0.8 vol. percent • aromatics limit increased from 30 to 35 vol. percent • distillation (T50 and T90) increased by 3 to 5 degrees F. • olefins unchanged
Energy Commission determines that
timetable to remove MTBE cannot be
advanced
ARB adopts Phase 3 RFG regulations
– Ethanol only permissible oxygenate
– Gasoline specifications changed
• lowers sulfur from 40 to 20 ppm
• lowers benzene from 1.0 to 0.8 vol. percent
• aromatics limit increased from 30 to 35 vol. percent
• distillation (T50 and T90) increased by 3 to 5 degrees F.
• olefins unchanged

Subsequent Actions - 2001
Subsequent Actions - 2001

US EPA denies request by California to receive waiver from the federal minimum oxygen requirement - June 12 – 70 percent of State’s gasoline must contain an
US EPA denies request by California to
receive waiver from the federal minimum
oxygen requirement - June 12
– 70 percent of State’s gasoline must contain an

oxygenate - increases to 80 % by 2003 – Failure to issue waiver will cost California
oxygenate - increases to 80 % by 2003
– Failure to issue waiver will cost California

consumers at least an additional 3 cents per gallon or $475 million per year
consumers at least an additional 3 cents per c o n s u m e r s
a t
l e a s t
a n
a d d i t i o n a l 3
c e n t s
p e r
gallon or $475 million per year

California Air Resources Board sues US EPA to obtain waiver - August 13 – Final arguments heard in Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals (February 2003) - awaiting decision
California Air Resources Board sues US EPA
to obtain waiver - August 13
– Final arguments heard in Ninth Circuit Court of
Appeals (February 2003) - awaiting decision

Subsequent Actions - 2002
Subsequent Actions - 2002

CEC revised estimates for MTBE phaseout – 3.4 to 6.4 cents per gallon – $540 MM to $1 billion per year Stillwater Report raised supply and infrastructure concerns – Estimated 5 to 10 percent decline in gasoline supply and increased potential for price spikes
CEC revised estimates for MTBE phaseout
– 3.4 to 6.4 cents per gallon
– $540 MM to $1 billion per year
Stillwater Report raised supply and
infrastructure concerns
– Estimated 5 to 10 percent decline in gasoline
supply and increased potential for price spikes

Legal action by Lake Tahoe utility – Several companies sued for MTBE contamination – Finding of “defective product” by jury – Settlement for $68 million
Legal action by Lake Tahoe utility
– Several companies sued for MTBE contamination
– Finding of “defective product” by jury
– Settlement for $68 million
